# Introduction {-}

Below is a list of resources you might find useful to navigate graduate school, and in particular the Econ Ph.D. Many of the resources below I first encountered in [this list](https://sites.google.com/site/mkudamatsu/tips4economists), which also has a lot more useful resources for every stage of your career as an economist.


# Researching

[Isaiah Berlin, "The Hedgehog and the Fox", 1953](https://www.blogs.hss.ed.ac.uk/crag/files/2016/06/the_hedgehog_and_the_fox-berlin.pdf)

[Axel Leijonhufvud, “Life Among the Econ,” Economic Inquiry 11, no. 3 (September 1, 1973): 327–37](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1465-7295.1973.tb01065.x)

[Ariel Rubinstein, "10 Q&A: Experienced Advice for “Lost” Graduate Students in Economics".](http://arielrubinstein.tau.ac.il/papers/10QA.pdf)

[Amy Finkelstein, “An unofficial guide to trying to do empirical work”, 2017](http://econ.lse.ac.uk/staff/spischke/phds/Amy%20Finkelstein%20IAP%20talk%2007.ppt)

[Hal R. Varian, “Big Data: New Tricks for Econometrics,” Journal of Economic Perspectives 28, no. 2 (May 2014): 3–28.](https://doi.org/10.1257/jep.28.2.3)

# Presenting

[Adam Guren, "How To Give a Lunch Talk"](http://people.bu.edu/guren/Guren_HowToGiveALunchTalk.pdf)  

[Jesse Shapiro, "How to give an applied micro talk"](https://www.brown.edu/Research/Shapiro/pdfs/applied_micro_slides.pdf) (applies equally well for applied macro talks).  

[David Levine, "David Levine's Cheap Advice for Presenting Results"](http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/LEVINE/cheap_advice.html#results)

[Tim Kehoe, "Tips on Preparing for the Workshop", May 2001](http://users.econ.umn.edu/~tkehoe/papers/tips.pdf)

[Goldstein and Evans, "Making a short presentation based on your research: 11 tips", 2016](http://blogs.worldbank.org/impactevaluations/making-short-presentation-based-your-research-11-tips)

[Matthew O. Jackson, "Notes on Presenting a Paper", Fall 1998](https://web.stanford.edu/~jacksonm/present.pdf)

# Writing

[Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz, "The Ten Most Important Rules of Writing Your Job Market Paper."](http://economics.harvard.edu/files/economics/files/tenruleswriting.pdf)  

[John Cochrane, "Writing Tips"](https://faculty.chicagobooth.edu/john.cochrane/research/papers/phd_paper_writing.pdf).  

[David Levine, "David Levine's Cheap Advice for Writing a Dissertation"](http://faculty.haas.berkeley.edu/LEVINE/cheap_advice.html#dissertation)

# Graphing

[Novartis, "Graphics Principles - Cheat Sheet V1.0"](https://www.psiweb.org/docs/default-source/2018-psi-conference-posters/48-julie-jones.pdf?sfvrsn=cb68dedb_4)

# Coding

[Matthew Gentzkow and Jesse M. Shapiro, "Code and Data for the Social Sciences: A Practitioner's Guide"](https://web.stanford.edu/~gentzkow/research/CodeAndData.xhtml)

[Michael Ernst, "Version control concepts and best practices."](https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~mernst/advice/version-control.html#best-practices)

[Benjamin S. Skrainka, "Enhance Your Productivity and Software Quality with Techniques from Silicon Valley"](http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~uctpbss/EconSite/Talks_files/Zurich-Sep2009.pdf)
